data.title: :arrow_up: language-go@0.41.0
Crash when quitting from two full-screen windows on Mac
data.body:
This is with Atom 1.3.0 on MacOS 10.11.2.

To reproduce:
- open a few files from a folder; it will create one Atom window
- open a few other files from another folder; it will create another Atom window
- make both windows full screen
- close all files in one of the windows; here you will note an issue already, that is that that window remains open; I would expect it to close itself, leaving the other window open only
- quit by doing CMD-Q, and Atom will crash

data.title: Wrap line at boundary if it includes a CJK character
data.body:
Fixes #9447.

This PR provides a different strategy for wrapping lines whenever CJK characters are involved. With this PR we try to detect a CJK character before or exactly at the desired wrap boundary: if we do, we perform the wrap; otherwise, we use the old line-breaking algorithm.

Although not compliant with the Unicode spec, this allows users to mix CJK characters with Latin ones without the need to introduce a complex line breaking logic.

Before: 

![screen shot 2015-12-10 at 10 29 22](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/482957/11711762/fc238466-9f28-11e5-83a9-cd92ce0940cc.png)

After: 

![screen shot 2015-12-10 at 10 29 44](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/482957/11711763/00ada642-9f29-11e5-9764-13b926a6193a.png)

/cc: @nathansobo @atom/feedback

data.title: Have a quick API for overriding the default value on config？
data.body:
Sometimes we want to override the default value in the dynamic scene.
Likes the `devicePixelRatio`.

I don't see an API to do it.

`config-schema.json`

``` js
{
  "devicePixelRatio":{
    "type":"number",
    "default":2,
    "minimum":1
  }
}
```

Currently, I use this way to hack it.

``` js

   this.config = require('./config-schema.json')

    // Overrides the default value of devicePixelRatio
   this.config.devicePixelRatio.default = devicePixelRatio

```

https://github.com/atom-minimap/minimap/pull/422/files

data.title: Add repo as a project folder, which was created in Ubuntu, in Windows crashes atom
data.body:
Steps to reproduce.

1) If you happen to use Dual-boot (Windows & Linux), create a Git repo under Linux with NPM packages included.
2) Come back to Windows and try to add it as project folder in Atom running on Windows.
3) Atom crashes.

_Affects current stable release 1.3_ too.

I tried to run above steps while keeping DevTools open and setting _Break on uncaught exceptions_ ON, and debugger stopped in `fs` module within `fs.readSync()` (which may be the starting point of trouble) and finally, Atom crashed when call to `GitRepository.open` happened within `repositoryForDirectorySync()` of `git-repository-provider` module.

data.title: Keybinding not consistent. Works one way through the command palette, different through the keybinding
data.body:
I'm trying to invoke a command from the `atom-turbo-javascript` package:

> End New Line CTRL-ENTER
> Terminates the current line with a colon or semicolon, followed with a new line. A comma is inserted when the cursor is inside an object literal, otherwise a semicolon is inserted.

I want the keybinding to be <kbd>⌘</kbd>+<kbd>⇧</kbd>+<kbd>⏎</kbd> and so in my `keymap.cson` I have:

```
'atom-text-editor':
    'cmd-shift-;': 'turbo-javascript:end-line'
    'cmd-shift-,': 'turbo-javascript:end-line-comma'
    'cmd-shift-enter': 'turbo-javascript:end-new-line'
```

Now, if I use cmd-shift-enter I get (i guess) the core functionality: a newline above the caret line. But if I search the same command in the command-palette, I see that it correctly has cmd-shift-enter and executing through the palette, it works!

![](http://i.imgur.com/FRVGTat.png)

So using the same shortcut the palette acknowledges directly, it gives me a new line above, not the turbo-javascript functionality. (in shift-cmd-enter order also doesn't work).

data.title: FYI: Atom quit unexpectedly
data.body:
So to replicate on _osx_:
1. open a project
2. hit `cmd` + `shift` + `w`

you should see a pop up stating "Atom quit unexpectedly"

I have not tested on other OSs, Hope this is a none issue!

data.title: Untitled buffers don't save language state
data.body:
This is a pretty common usage scenario for me as I open a temporary tab in language repos to test out changes that I make:
1. Open a new untitled buffer
2. Set the language to anything other than Plain Text (eg Java)
3. write some text
4. Reload Atom

**Expected**: Language is still Java
**Actual**: Language is reset to Plain Text

Atom 1.4.0-dev-77a5409 **non safe-mode**, Windows 10 x64

/cc @as-cii

data.title: Add a core config `core.automaticallyUpdate` to disable Atom autoupdate.
data.body:
This PR does following:
- Added a config `core.automaticallyUpdate`. This config is enabled by default, but if user disable it, the new Atom window won't check update/schedule update on startup.
- I didn't observer the config changes after initialization, which means if user change the automaticallyUpdate config, it won't change the autoupdate behavior until user quit and start Atom again, but we could observer this changes if we think it's necessary.
- Remove the build option `--no-auto-update` and revert all related code introduced in https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/8721

What I have tested:
- run the `scrip/build` to build a new Atom.app.
- noticed the `enableAutoupdate` is selected by default, and the checkUpdate button showed up in Atom menu.
- disable `enableAutoupdate` option, open a new Atom window, the checkUpdate button disappeared from Atom menu.
- Note that since the build of Atom don't have certs, so I can't tell if the download is happening or not.

data.body:
Hi guys,

Atom is repeatedly crashing on windows (it happens after about 5-10 minutes of usage). (version 1.2.4)

Nothing seems to fix the issue.

Unfortunately, when it crashes, it produces no reports that I can see.

The interesting part is that I can't re-open atom until I reboot windows. Even attempting to run it with the --safe tag makes no difference, it simply will not open. 3 processes start, and I can see them in task manager, but nothing I do causes any windows to open.

data.title: Opening files with different encoding than UTF-8 is really slow
data.body:
Hello,

I have a file that has characters different than UTF-8. It takes really long to change the encoding of the file to the correct one. When I chage the default encoding in Atom, opening such a file takes very long too. 

**Steps to reproduce**
- Download the following file [test.txt](https://github.com/atom/atom/files/55197/test.txt)
- Set the default encoding of Atom to Western(Windows 1252)
- Open the file you just downloaded in Atom

Opening will take pretty long(on my machine it takes around 10 seconds)
When changing the default encoding back to UTF-8 in Atom and opening the file, it loads very fast.

**Version of Atom I tried that were affected**
- 1.3.0 beta6
- 1.2.4

**Operating Systems tested on**
- Windows 7
- Windows 10

data.title: Won't run after a "Not responding" on Win7
data.body:
After an hour or two Atom goes blank "Not responding". It takes a system reboot to run it again.
I've noticed there's at least 2 `Atom.exe` processes still running in the Task manager which won't end.

data.title: Increase stack trace size limit to 30
data.body: Heads up @kevinsawicki.
